what other people really admire this company for I didn't ask anybody to do or say

um in my case a little bit different um to what was discussed I and I think back U an important point I guess in in my
view of business and and and my whole concept of building trust both with an organization and with the community
really came back when I came back from the business school back in ' 87 to the Philippines the Philippines country of
88 million people um 30% live uh below the poverty line um another way of
looking at it is 90% of all households in the Philippines earn uh maybe about $600 a month or less yet have the

country uh uh infrastructures and and and ways of solving problems that involve uh a lot of sophistication and I
came back uh to a very different environment and there and then it struck me really upon landing and in the first
weeks of of of working back in my country that there was a component missing in the business equation I
picked up at the business school and I found it I felt it very profoundly uh on one hand uh I felt I had some new tools
some new ways of looking at things uh but the whole reality of the economic environment I I was faced with uh was
radically different um the whole concept of Institutions growing building market share uh becoming important here in the
United States you know people are loaded they're respected as they grow in size in the Philippines trust breaks down uh
you're mistrusted if you're too large an entity within the kind of environment we have where there's this disparity in
income and uh it made me think hard KN about um some of the um lessons I'd learned but I really felt that there
were significant lessons and significant parts of the equation missing and I proceeded to Just Adjust really through
gutfield and uh and add some new elements into the equation um a Social Development agenda became very important
to me and it started to run parallel to the way I ran the business um it was
there in parallel not integrated in any way and began to sort of come out in different ways of of of building trust
with these new communities um one example for example we a with a group in in in many businesses in the Philippines
but real estate has been something that's been very close to to the history of our company we won a large property
um in the second largest city in in the Philippines um and we wanton it from a Government auction it was very large and
with it came a lot of uh informal settlers and uh the government told us look you've won fair and square and you
know we will give you support with police Etc to get rid and and and evacuate uh and and and um and ask the
informal settlers to leave and if we need to use for so be it and and I felt right from the very start you know this
is this is wrong I mean the law is on your side but you're immediately going to create tension in a community where
you're coming in uh uh to begin with um and so we started with a whole new
concept of of of of lessening that tension right off which the law said it was on my side you know we could uh we
could remove the squatters but we said no let's not do that let's not start off on on on that position and we worked
with the foundation and people who knew about working with um informal settlers building communities we worked with the
government and said do you have land that's extra they found land and we found a way of U relocating the
squatters um and bringing them to a whole new area uh we helped organize
themselves we gave them land that they could then own and it was a cost it was a cost element that we that was unforeseen in in in the in the purchase
of this property but 3 years later we built a whole set of new Dynamics with that Community what started off as a
very low trust environment uh became one of trust and we were able to do many other things in that environment because
of this Social Development agenda we were able to add in there were many other examples as we moved on but over
the years after that key moment uh of realization um what's happened in our
group and um is that we've brought the Social Development agenda to work more closely with the Strategic intent uh of
the company and what was gutfield for me at the time and and we began to develop it as as just an instinct um I was
pleasantly surprised I was invited um by the Harvard Business School to join their um visiting committee and I would
touch on this topic and at the very beginning there wasn't much resonance uh in the group as we discussed these things but then over time I found myself
actually by luck and by accident in a breakout group of one of these visiting committees and ran into uh I guess the
uh the social Enterprise Group which was founded by Jim Austin and cash rangan and and Michael Chu and I suddenly saw
uh an intellect ual framework uh that was beginning to shape up at the business school with respect to this merging of the Social Development agenda
and and strategic intent and that fundamentally began to change the way uh I did things in the Philippines and and
and that interaction as well with business school helped me put a framework uh an intellectual framework around what was originally an instinct
and and and since then it's basically transformed the way we do business um in
a country like ours you're really as you grow uh a business you're really dealing with people and touching uh people and
customers at at much lower levels than the income scale dealing with them building trust with these communities
we're in water distribution we deal with people in very very poor communities in on the cell phone business we're the
second largest mobile operator uh selling cell phones to people at at at the low end of of the income scale is
radically different to anything that you've done on the top end and um so those were my my key moments just a
realization that that a Social Development agenda could be integrated into strategy and become a very powerful
for for success in a country like ours uh I've always believed in in in the capitalist system I believe that it's a
way to bring a country forward but I have to admit that when I came back uh to the Philippines at the time a
significant component of a successful equation as I felt it was missing and and and that's evolved over time a lot

striking how much these moments that were difficult moments in various ways in your case being

meetings uh that everyone who comes to me can speak up speak their mind without
fear of retaliation or people saying that's not true we're being very defensive and and the people have to be

for 2009 or there we cancel all that stuff all of it you know meetings trips
travel you may name it to focus on the fact that we're in the middle of a real crisis you you better have a sense of
urgency again I I'm surprised that people don't have it uh uh you have to
have fortitude and I I heard jayl mention before the ability to act a lot of people don't have the ability to act

age well and so you have to have
you have to have a awful lot of fortitude to do the not just yourself by the whole management team to do the

surprised a lack of fortitude on the parts of some people just to figure out the right thing and then to do it and

other deal with I have to deal with so fortitude is a really hard a hard thing you have to be very disciplined and I I

some decisions on the spot reviewing facts and information but this discipline again

uh client service levels and and a regular consistent review of where you stand why you're there and again very
